Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Resarch: EAGER: Mapping small molecules in the root meristem
Award.AbstractNarration: It is well appreciated that plants have roots which serve many essential functions, such as structurally supporting the plant and taking up nutrients from the soil to promote the growth of the plant. But what is not clear is the chemical composition of different root compartments and how these chemicals are used to signal the growth of the plant. The research team hopes to discover the identity and function of these chemical compounds by making a chemical map of where these chemical compounds are located in the root structure. They will do that by directing a stream of tiny droplets onto a cut section of the root and letting the resulting droplet splash enter a mass spectrometer, a device that can determine the identity and the amount of each compound dissolved in the scattered droplets. By mounting the root section on a slide that be moved right and left as well as up and down, a two-dimensional map will be recorded of the compounds present in the root. They believe this approach will provide new information related to how roots of plants function.<br/><br/>Metabolite and lipid signaling molecules are critical for proper regulation of development in multicellular organisms. The chemical properties of these small molecules enable them to cross cell membranes, function as highly specific ligands to protein receptors, and dynamically convert between different molecular species on short time scales. These abilities facilitate rapid communication of developmental cues across tissues. Defects in the biosynthesis, perception, or metabolism of these compounds can lead to aberrant tissue formation and disease. Despite the critical importance of small molecules, most of our understanding of their function is derived from indirect measurements of these compounds. The investigators will utilize desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry imaging (DESI-MSI) to directly measure small molecules in distinct developmental regions of root tissue. The root meristem is an excellent model for this work because cells are organized along a longitudinal developmental gradient, with pluripotent stem cells located at the tip of the root, and differentiated cells localized towards the direction of the shoot. This approach is yielding the identification of novel small molecule regulators of development. Combining DESI-MSI with traditional molecular biology approaches will enable characterization of new roles of metabolite and lipid signaling compounds in stem cell decisions, with implications in both plant and human research.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change is a serious and escalating major threat to the lives and livelihoods of farmers. Severe weather resulting from climate change has already cost US farmers billions of dollars in crop loss. Therefore, there is an urgent need to generate new agricultural solutions that can promote plant growth, especially in harsh environmental conditions, such as drought. This project applied a technology called desorption electrospray ionization mass spectrometry imaging (DESI-MSI) to map the natural chemistry of plant stem cells, which are essential for growth and response to stress. The ultimate objective of this work was to understand the molecular basis for how plants grow, which could lead to new agrochemical treatments that can promote yield for farmers.

This work revealed tissue-specific distribution patterns of hundreds of natural chemicals (metabolites and lipids) in developing maize roots. Developing maize roots contain both stem cell tissue and mature (non-stem cell) tissue, enabling direct comparison of chemicals in both types of tissue. We found dozens of compounds that were highly enriched in stem cells, the cells that are essential for tissue formation and growth. One class of metabolites that had striking enrichment patterns were the citric acid cycle (CAC) metabolites. CAC metabolites are highly conserved and are essential for cellular energy production in all plants and animals. We found that certain CAC metabolites have specific effects on stem cell behavior and on plant growth. For instance, succinate and aconitate both increased root growth, but they did so in different ways. Succinate promoted stem cell divisions and aconitate increased root cell length. We generated plants with either enhanced succinate or aconitate production and found that both methods could increase growth, even in conditions that mimic drought stress. The major results of this project were published in Nature Communications (Zhang and Noll et al. 2023, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-023-38150-z). In addition, this work led to two patent applications describing novel methods to promote crop growth. Overall, this project uncovered novel roles for highly conserved CAC metabolites, and additionally demonstrated that mapping the distribution of small molecules in the developing root can be used to discover new plant growth regulators.
